Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A community seismic experiment targeting the pre-, syn-, and post-rift evolution of the Mid Atlantic US margin
Award.AbstractNarration:
The structure and evolution of the Eastern North America margin are the focus of this GeoPRISMS community seismic experiment. The data obtained will form a fundamental framework to address several aspects of the Program's Rift Initiation and Evolution initiative: how tectonic, magmatic, erosional and depositional processes interact; the role of mantle dynamics in ongoing deformation along this passive margin; the impact of ancient regional structure on long-term evolution that shapes present-day distribution of geologic activity.

A year-long ocean bottom seismometer array (OBSIP- 30 instruments) will extend onshore station coverage (EarthScope Transportable Array, ~30 sites relevant) across Cape Hatteras. Additional transects of densely-spaced seismometers will record seismic waves that travel across the coastline, documenting more detailed structure from the continental slope through the coastal plain. Multi-channel seismic reflection data will be openly available upon completion of a training workshop that will conduct basic processing. Similarly, seismic refraction data will be distributed for a second training workshop. Data for investigations using natural seismic events will also be openly available via the IRIS Data Management Center. Station spacing and array aperture target crust and upper mantle imaging. The experiment design builds on existing data to address current scientific questions, emphasizing both deeper structure, which will illuminate driving forces for ongoing evolution, and modernizing shallow structural constraints, to better document surface response records and their relationship to the history of glacial, sea level, depositional, and magmatic loading.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

We gathered active-source and passive seismic data along the mid-Atlantic coast of East North America Margin (ENAM) in the context of a community-driven experiment with completely open data access. The data can be used by all members of the community to investigate research problems related to rifting and the evolution of continental margins. As such, the acquisition of this data set is an important first step in the Implementation Plan for this GeoPRISMS primary site. In the Spring of 2014, broadband ocean-bottom seismometers were deployed offshore Cape Hatteras to record for one year. This instrument array essentially complemented the Earthscope Transportable Array of broadband seismometers on land. In September and October of 2014, marine seismic reflection ad refraction data were gathered with the R/V Marcus Langseth and the R/V Oceanus. Last, land explosion seismic data were collected in North Carolina and Virginia in the Summer of 2015. The study area encompassed roughly 400 km by 500 km area across the rifted margin, from unextended continental lithosphere onshore to mature oceanic lithosphere offshore. The active-source, short-period instruments were arranged in two margin-parallel lines and two major dip lines. The broadband seismometers provided more uniform areal coverage.

 

The experiment was designed to allow for multi-scale imaging of crustal and mantle lithospheric structure and stratigraphy, deposition and deformation of the sediment cover. To best meet the science goals, we chose the instrument design after a community straw poll and input from several meetings. The data can be used to investigate 1) the relationship between continental thinning across the margin and syn-rift magmatism, 2) extent of seaward-dipping reflections, potential lava flows, beneath the continental shelf, 3) the onset of seafloor spreading, 4) the structure and origin of the enigmatic Blake Spur Magnetic Anomaly, 5) post-rift subsidence of the cooling margin, and 6) landslides from the edge of the continental shelf.

 

After completion of the fieldwork we archived the seismid data in the IRIS Data Management center and the marine seismic Data Portal of LDEO and UTIG. We reported on the new data set through a project web site, and several talks at professional meetings and science symposiums. In the summer of 2015 we held two five-day workshops at LDEO and UTIG to train students and early-career scientists in the use of marine seismic reflection and refraction data from the ENAM project. The ENAM seismic data have subsequently been used as a basis for further science investigations of the mid-Atlantic margin of United States.

 

Over the course of the project, PI Van Avendonk worked with two graduate students at UTIG to compile a global list of oceanic crustal thickness measurements from the existing literature. He showed that crustal thickness varies with plate age, and that the breakup of Pangaea was likely followed by abnormal cooling of the mid-ocean ridges in the Atlantic and Indian oceans. This study is important background information for other GeoPRISMS studies. The results were presented at the 2016 Fall AGU meeting, and they are published in a new article in Nature Geoscience.

 

Broader Impacts:

All of the data acquired by this project was made available to the community immediately, which enabled the broadest possible benefit for science and education. This multi-faceted seismic experiment also offered an immense opportunity for education of young scientists. Before the start of the fieldwork we solicited applications from students and early-career scientists. These participants often hail from universities where sea-going experience is otherwise difficult to get. They helped gather, archive and process the field data. Several of the students later also participated in the processing workshops. The ENAM community seismic project will further  impact the general population by enabling studies related to geohazards problems along the continental margin.
